Reminds me of a combination of the good parts of Fable and an Elder Scrolls game. Lots of side quests and dialog options (if you want that). Fast travel AND a decent run speed make exploring not a chore.  Cons: Story is incredibly bland. Yet another 'chosen one with no memories please save the world' snooze-fest. Every quest is a fetch quest or a 'go here and activate 4 different towers and come back, thanks' deal. Random battles, as in enemies will just appear out of nowhere and attack you. That last one would be bad, but there are a lot of enemies that can fly and cast magic, so they spend most of the time hovering just outside your attack range spaming magic blasts. The menus are a slog to get through. Lore books everywhere filled with really boring, needless notes. Some of the worst fantasy names this side of Dungeon Siege 3.  If you can grab the complete edition for ~$5 and you really, really want to play another Elder Scrolls inspired game it's not a bad deal, but be warned that it is aggressivly dull underneath the pretty paintjob.

Kingdoms of Amalur sure feels like a refreshing wind after trying out a bunch of different mmorpgs and rpgs.  This game combines the combat of many console-esque titles like God of War and Darksiders, with the lore and rpg-aspect of games like Dragon Age and Vampire the Masquerade (roughly speaking).   Lore  After playing around 12 hours I was feeling fairly immersed in the world of Amalur. Bit for bit you learn more and more about the lore, machinations of the world and all the colourful characters that inhabit it. You can go further by looking for 'lorestones' across maps and reading books/scrolls that will teach you more about the Kingdom of Amalurs history, alas it is not mandatory for those who prefer to avoid lore alltogether and focus on the other aspects of the game. But for those who love lore like me, you'll notice that there has been placed a lot of thought into the this aspect of the game. I'm not aware if it's R.A. Salvatore or someone else who wrote the story, but it seems well thought out in overall.   Size of game-world  The game itself seems to be fairly large - the worldmap is quite grand & you travel between subzones on it. 'Clearing' each area can sometimes take a couple of hours - so this game isn't really lacking content as to say. This game has easily 100+ hours of content to go through.   Quests  Some people voice concern that the game is too 'grindy' and compare it to games like World of Warcraft where you kill x amount of wild boars, and then move on to kill x amount of kobolds, etc. Amalur has these kind of quests too, but they are well mixed among very different and personalized quests which in my opinion makes the former ones bearable to a larger extent.   Visuals  The visuals look good, even if you find odd low-res textures here and there which isn't as bad as it might sound as long as you don't expect ultra setting Skyrim ENB with high res textures-quality. Kingdoms of Amalur can also utilize the ENB-injector technology and give the world a more vivid look which I recommend for everyone who aren't satisfied with the default visuals of the game. You can grab it off the Skyrim Nexus site.   Classes  One of the games absolute strongpoints is the 'class'-system that Kingdom of Amalur has. You have a lot of options to combine and customize your own 'class' - mix and match skills of different kinds. The game has the classic 'Warrior, rogue and sorcerer'-theme, but you can create hybrids of all combinations - and the ability to respecc for a sum of gold gives you a chance to try out different kinds of gameplay without having to create a new character every time.   Combat  The combat is fast paced and fun. You unlock and learn new kinds of attacks and 'combos' as the game progresses and you level up your character. The many kind of enemies and their behaviour means that you can't just spam attacks all the time (if you play on hard-difficulty), but you actually need to stop and block, or dodge attacks to be able to win. Thinking ahead is key, for example when positioning yourself so that all the enemies get in a big line infront of you, prior to using that powerful sword-attack that hits everything in a line up front.   Minor flaws of the game  My only gripe so far with this game has been minor annoyances like the FoV (which you can modify using a widescreen modification - google it!) and things like weapons sheathing too fast, both in and out of combat. I'd like to see more RP-aspects and abilities for the character, but seeing it being a single-player game - it's forgivable. The game is also not open-world, but rather 'instanced'. Still the 'instanced' areas are often pretty large, way larger than what Dragon Age had for instance - thus making it forgivable too.   Conclusion  In overall this game is fairly good if you're looking for decent story, engaging combat and many hours of gameplay. A little polish wouldn't hurt here and there though as I earlier mentioned. Unfortunately since the studio behind this game went into bankruptcy we can't be expecting any more updates, which is sad since the title has potential and I would personally be interested in purchasing a sequel if there ever was one.   Rating  Giving this game a 8 out of 10.

The best way I can think of describing it would be if The Elder Scrolls and Fable had a baby, and it was ♥♥♥♥ing amazing, with the sick quests of Oblivion and Morrowind combined with the combat style of Fable, but made way deeper and with enemies that aren't completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. This is one of those underrated games that got overshadowed by Skyrim because they came out around the same time, and the company was pretty new and unknown. But there are major differences between Kingdoms and Skyrim most noteably, Kingdoms doesn't freeze, get lost, or crash like Skyrim does, especially the xbox version. HOWEVER this game was made for Windows 7, and the company didn't survive, which stinks btw... so there are crashes on Windows 10. Every time I tried to play this game on W10 it did crash after about 15 minutes of play, and others have said the same...so if you don't run Windows 7...you may want to pass on this one, even though it is a really great game.  Kingdoms is really well written, engaging, and fun to explore. The map is huge, AND most importantly, its easy to follow. There are a lot of cool features like dispel chests which are challenging to unlock but hold a lot of valuable stuff in them. Although learning to open them can be a real pain in the fanny because if you fail, you suffer health loss, but they will still be unlocked. There are chests to find, tons of them...and lore stones that when you find and activate them, they reveal narration of the backstory. There is a lot going for this game, it's visually beautiful, reminiscent of Fable, but also holds its own original story and style, and great music, and so is the voice acting. The combat is fun with lots of weapons, spells, etc, to aid you. But the best feature of this game is the combat because it doesn't require the player to be at a high level before they get powerful weapons and spells. You get that pretty darn early so that is a plus in my book. There are 3 game difficulty levels, and several races to choose and build your character from male and female. Human and other. I have logged about 90 hours on this game (mostly offline not recorded by Steam)... and I still haven't finished everything. There are a ton of side quests but not necessary for leveling up , but can be over-whelming if you start too many at once, which is very easy to do. Basically it is open-world, however the story is linear. The character design and environments were created by Todd McFarlane (creator of Spawn) so ...you know it's great. This really is an overlooked game...but it plays very well, and you should check it out IF you run Windows 7.

Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a colossal and deep RPG with a beautiful atmosphere.  The world you can explore is huge, even though it is parted into many little regions which are designed rather linear. However, this makes it easier to find every quest and not to miss something important. There are tons of caves, cities, castles and forests that are enjoyable to explore. Besides, you can fast-travel to any location you have visited so far, which is a great tool.  There are three skilltrees in which you can invest , you do not have to limit your points to one of them. You can mix them up in any way you want to. You will encounter several fateweavers in the game which can reset your skill points for a bit some money, depending on your level. The level cap in this game is 40.  The story itself is pretty cool and presented very well but gets a bit lengthy towards the end, yet the ending itself is spectacular again. There are several moments where you can influence certain outcomes with your decisions.  There is a extremely large number of available side-quests in this game, I ended up having completed around 300 of them (with both DLC’s). Some of them go with the standard pattern like finding some reagents or killing some mobs while on the other hand there are some pretty big side-quests that bring a little story on their own which are very entertaining to follow.  The game has 3 difficulty-settings and I recommend you to play it on hard since it’s still pretty easy on medium as long as you’re not fighting large groups of enemies, especially towards the end when you got the best kinds of armor and weapons.  There is a variety of different enemies that behave different in battle which leads to entertaining fights. The Gameplay itself is pretty good in my eyes, especially the combats are very dynamic.   The graphics are quite good for early 2012 and the world is designed with a love for detail. You’ll find many different environments that feel alive. The great music of this game strengthens the atmosphere even more.  On the downside, there are some bugs in this game which will never get fixed because the studio that produced this game went bankrupt. However, most of these bugs just make some quest items being stuck in your inventory after you completed the quest or other minor things that one can oversee.  In Amalur, you can acquire various houses in which you can store your items, you can even earn an own arena and a mining company which gain you money over time.  There are various weapon types with different advantages and downsides which brings some additional diversity.  Regarding the DLC’s, I can greatly recommend you “The Legend of Dead Kel” and “Teeth of Naros”, which both have a great storyline and add another big map part to the already huge map each. However, the “Weapons & Armor Bundle” just adds a bit of loot that falls off quite quick and in my opinion is not worth the money.  All in All, I truly recommend giving Kingdoms of Amalur a try, for it a large and beautiful game with a wonderful atmosphere.    P.S.: Sorry for my bad English, it’s not my native language.

This game surprised me. I read some reveiws that said it was surprisingly good but it still caught me off guard. I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I am. It's a pleasant feeling to be surprised these days by a game that seemed to be so resoundingly denounced on release. I highly recommend playing it, even with all its' flaws, because it's fun and familiar.   Let's get the bad out of the way: -The first 30 minutes. It's awkward to control without tweaking because it was absolutely designed to be used with a controller. If you have one, I recommend using it. If not, tinker with sensitivity and hotkeys to make it more playable. The defacto tutorial level is unimpressive, slightly confusing, and rather buggy. It takes you through each class and weapon type but you don't have to commit just yet. At this point it seems to be super linear, on rails type of game but push through to the first village and it opens up. -The camera. It takes getting used to. The third person perspective is unfortunate. While I generally play in third person, not having the option to move the camera is frustrating at times. This is one of the areas where it's design for consoles is very evident. -Vanilla. This isn't really a negative or a positive. It's what you expect from a game like this. Some fetch quests, some kill quests, some steal quests, a few factions and schools to join, and the RPG trinity of classes. Even with some multiclassing, it's still an expected experience class wise.  The Good: -Rich lore. If you didn't know, it is written by RA Salvatore and it shows. Some of the stories feel familiar if you are a fan of his books. One of the first questlines, The House of Ballads, is very interesting and they continue in the vein throughout. -Tons of side quests. You can get lost in sidequests for a few hours with each new area and those discovered in the wild. -Combat seems simple on the surface (and can remain so if you desire) but with multiclassing can become dynamic and engaging. -Crafting! I generally only craft because I have to but this system makes it easy. It is not particularly deep or impressive in it's installation but it is perfect for players like me who don't generally dump a ton of time into it. I like that you can craft usable items at any point no matter the skill level. Strength of weapons or armor are based on components used and NOT player skill. A small but important distiction.  This game is everything you expect from an open world RPG in the Elder Scrolls vein. Why would that be a bad thing? Just because it has been done before doesn't mean it can't be done again and done well. Pick it up and have fun with it, I know I have.

I inititally dismissed KoA when it was released, thinking it was just another bland RPG game. However after buying it on a whim I was blown away by the amount of content. The quest system is solid and will keep you busy for the forseeable future, and the game is brilliantly optimized.  As of writing this review I am not even half way through my first playthrough (finishing the main quest lines in both DLC zones). There are three distinct classes to level in depending on whether you want to be a ranger, who favours bows, a mage, who can summon powerful AoE spells, or the cheapest class I have found, the warrior. You are not limited to one class or the other and can make just about any character you could so desire. but the only way to get the very most powerful perks is to invest all of you skill points in to one skill branch.  The crafting system is solid, allowing you to make your own potions, weapons and armor, as well as gems that infuse your items with other powers (Health or mana regen, poison damage, extra armor). Crafting your own gear is recommended as anything you make with high enough ingredients will out perform any weapon or armor piece found in the world.  The game world itself is huge, and given that your character does not have a mount, you will be walking everywhere (fast travel becomes available after visiting a location). There are many different biomes that you will visit on your journey from lush jungles, to scorched deserts, to damp marshes.  It is true that no game is perfect, and I am quite sad that the developer shut down after this game was released, my personal rating for this game is: Story 7/10 The game starts in a new way to anything I have ever seen before, but still has some cliche moments Gameplay 8/10 The fighting system is a breath of fresh air to me after skyrim, it feels fluid and quick swapping lets you juggle your opponents Graphics 7/10 Don't expect crysis the RPG the game does look a bit cartoony but it earns the high rating because it fits so well with the game Sound 9/10 The ingame soundtrack is beautiful and the little details and subtle sounds bring this game to life, an absolute pleasure with headphones  This has become my favourite RPG in my steam library and I cannot recommend it highly enough, the game might be a bit slow for some people to begin with but after you begin levelling up you choose the pace

I purchased Kingdoms of Amalur on Steam as a complete package for $11.99 which included all of the DLC and finished the main story in 53 hours. As with most games I play, I finished all the side quests I came across.   Graphics – Great  I loved the graphics in KOA. There is a strong a vivid use of color and the world is filled with detail. Animations are fluid and my PC never once stuttered the frame rate from a constant 60 fps. The environments could have used a little more variety as by endgame you will grow tired of the same recycled assets.   Music – Fair  The music in KOA is well orchestrated but the songs lack depth and variety. More songs would have been a plus as a large amount of time is spent in each area before going to the next and this can have you listening to the same loop for many hours at a time.   Cinematics – Good  Picture the same dialogue cutscenes as KOTOR or Mass Effect. The dialogue itself is very well written but unlike the Mass Effect series, you may not find yourself delving into the various conversation options. The characters and their backgrounds just weren’t interesting enough for me. The choices during conversations also lacked the Mass Effect style feeling of autonomy. You could make good or evil choices but it never mattered much. “Quick Time” events in combat are a cool sight to see.   Story – Good  As RPGs go, this story is original and kept me interested enough to finish the game to see what happens. I did not grow attached to any of the side characters or find them interesting. This game is really all about you. The main villain(s) were menacing but far from the kind of evil we love to hate.   Control – Great  I had no issues with the controls. They are very simple and easy to learn. The UI was easy enough to use. The awkward camera may startle you at first but you quickly get used to it.   Gameplay – Fair  I played as a melee class so your experience may vary. Combat in the beginning is fun but quickly grows stale. All I really had to do was click mouse 1 until everything died. Even on the hard setting, combat becomes too easy as you gain better weapons and armor. You completely overpower everything and I did not die once the entire game. I also never needed any of the consumable items with the exception of a very rare healing potion.   Content – Good  There is plenty to do here and the game’s zones adjust to your level so you are free to do as little or as much as you want to for side quests. The loot you find is very rewarding in the beginning of the game but by the middle, I was scrapping everything I found for parts. I had over five million gold with nothing to spend it on.   Value – Great  For $12 I had 53 hours of fun. The game is huge and kept me playing until I finished. I did not feel inclined to play through the DLC quest lines. In my opinion, they weren’t worth it.   Recommended – Yes  I recommend this game for the price I paid. In my opinion, this game is worth $20 or less. It is currently $19.99 on Steam without the DLC.

I'm going to compare this game to Witcher 2 and Skyrim because they are my two favourite RPGs and many people have played them.  Secondly, if you're going to buy this game, it goes on sale fairly often so I would suggest waiting for a sale  KoA does a lot of things right but a lot is sincerely average: KoA has the option to completely change your character's style and perks at any point meaning that you can change the type of character you have whenever you want to try something new. This is cool but it made me feel like a second playthrough would be fairly pointless as I have already tried all the character builds in one playthrough. Playing through the whole game the environments are beautiful and varied.  The look of the game is more animated than Skyrim or the Witcher and this gives it a 'friendlier' look, this is either good or bad depending on your preference. The fighting mechanic is fun and fairly reactive, being more like the Witcher than Skyrim. You can dodge and mix spells and abilities seamlessly in with melee or ranged combat.  I found the game too easy, playing the whole thing on hard and never really struggling, eventually you become so powerful that you cannot be beaten and fighting creatures becomes tedious even though the fighting mechanic is fun The main story line is decent and has some originality but is definitely not on the level of the Witcher (but few games are in my opinion) The faction storylines are fun and to the point but fairly predictable But the side quests have some cool little twists and original little stories. The soundtrack is terribly repetitive and NPCs like talking during battles which results in you missing half of what they are saying because the background noise is so loud Some reviewers found the voice acting sketchy but I did not notice any problems There is a lot of lore to be discovered which is nice for people into that and it isn't thrown in your face so you can ignore it if you want Lastly, you can sell any item to any merchant and they all have unlimited funds (because running around trying to sell things in Skyrim is pretty annoying)  Pros: Beautiful environments Great fighting mechanic Lots of lore Decent storyline Recustomising your character at any point  Cons: Too easy (for a Dark Souls person) Predictable  Repetitive soundtrack and some difficulty hearing NPCs explain key story points (which they don't repeat) No point in a second playthrough  So in conclusion KoA is a fun game that I would recommend to any RPG fan, but I personally would not rank it above either Skyrim or the Witcher 2

Summary: This is one of the best purchases I ever made on Steam. I've always enjoyed fantasy RPGs, and this little know game is a solid 5 star gem of one. The game starts with you, the protagonist, waking up in the Well of Souls, a so far unnsuccesful experiment designed to resurrect the dead. Your resurrection has also imbued you with the unique trait that you are free from the concept of fate, to which previously every single person in the world had been. You and your knewfound gifts are then tasked to explore Amalur and take down the Tuatha, an army of evil immortals hell bent on the world domination and your personal demise. Some of the defining features of this game:   Combat: Some of the best combat I've ever experienced in an RPG. Simple enough in concept, its all about timing your clicks and mastering weapon combinations while weaving in spells when necessary. But what makes it awesome is how insanely good it feels. Think Shadow of Mordor, but faster and more epic. Plus there are so many weapons with so many stats that it almost feels like the fantasy version of Borderlands 2.   Upgrade sytem: Brilliant. Instead of forcing you decide to upgrade stats without having any clue what they do only to later have you regret your choices, KOA gives you three different upgrade trees: Might, Sorcery and Finesse. Unlike many RPGs, there is not an optimal way to spend skill points, rather upgrading is more about giving you flexibility in how you want to play. You can go full man mode hammer smashing tank with might, ultmate arcane master, become the deadliest assassin with finesse, or any combination of the three. Points in each tree unlock unique spells, weapon combos or perks that make levelling up fun and impactful. Best of all, at any point in the game you reset all your points and reallocate them however you choose (for some gold).   Story and World Design: Beautiful and original, KOA with leave you breathless at some of the worlds you find yourself in. The map is nearly Skyrim level huge, but also very well varied. There are dark caves, snowy mountains, massive forests, brooding castles, wide plains and many more, all populated with unique monsters, races and quests. You will never feel like the game is too small The characters and voice acting are spot on, if you like immersive RPGs then this one takes the cake. The art design is much more fantastical than many traditional RPGs, but I personally enjoyed it. Oh, and while there is a reasonable amount of walking, there is also a lot to do and see along the way, so I personally didn't feel like I was playing Hiking Simulator/Skyrim.   Main and side quests. With 60+ hours on this game as of this review, I have only just beaten the main quests, one faction quest (probably about a solid 10 hours itself) and a handful of side quests. This game has soooooo much to do that I'm not sure I'll ever get to it all. Oh, and I haven't even bought any of the DLC.   The only real flaw in this game is that it is pretty easy. Dying doesn't punish you at all if you save properly, and gold is so plentiful that after a point I never had less than 20 or so potions in my inventory, meaning as long as you restock enough you really shouldn't ever die. Even for your first time I would reccomend playing on hard difficulty.   Conclusion: A beautiful story, fun class/upgrade system and an immersive world collide to create this action RPG masterpiece. This was one of the few single player games that I found myself able to enjoy for hours upon nonstop hours. And for 20 bucks full price, I can't think of a better value on Steam right now.

It's like a linear version of Elder Scrolls if you've ever played one of them. Fully voiced, lots of lore, decent story, quests occasionally have options to alter the outcome, graphics are crisp, animations are mostly clean, there's detail in level design, lootz, crafting (optional) and a 'double layered' level up system (able to tech into multiple trees and choose one passive perk). In a nutshell it's a dungeon crawler in 3rd person instead of top-down.  Perhaps my favorite part about Amalur aside from above is the feeling of not being tethered to the game in order to notice progression. I can play for just 15 minutes and actually accomplish something.  On a minor negative note, Amalur does not give the full freedom other games allow. The player can not jump and the player can not decide to step off a cliff on whim; there are set locations to allow dropping into water or down a cliff-side. Fortunately these limitations do not or hinder gameplay.  Combat is straight forward and fairly rewarding. Left click to continue swinging, instill a pause or hold the click to start a special attack. The player can also mix in magic or swap weapons on the fly to make some interesting combos and setups. Though combat may seem too basic the AI does its job in finding those holes in defenses and can manage to really take a chunk of health. While left clicking is easy, positioning amongst groups of enemies is where the player needs to maintain control even though the AI isn't the smartest.  I would recommend Amalur to anybody who likes leveling up and combining classes. The game actually feels like a dungeon crawler but from a behind the shoulder perspective.  I would also highly recommend downloading the YSA mod which balances the game to make Hard mode actually hard and Normal not such an cakewalk.  Additional Thought: It would be nice if Amalur was coop multiplayer though it does a great job as a singleplayer game. If War in the North mixed with Amalur...

Underrated RPG  I bought this game without any anticipations and for what it is I had a lot of fun, of course it's not the next skyrim or dragon age origins, but there are worse Rpgs to play than this. Up: - A big, open world with plenty to explore and varriang landscapes (lush forests, dry deserts, damp swamps, etc.) - Really intuitive active combat it has some elements of darksiders and devil may cry (you can change between main and secondary weapons on the fly, use magic and can string together long combos *although therefore I recommend playing with a controller) - Quiet unique main story and setting (you are being killed and revived and therefore being able to change fate itself and later you also get information about your past before you were killed) - Crafting system (you can salvage any weapon/armor, except legendary and sets and get parts to craft your own weapon/armor and name it) - Dialogue system (sometimes you are able to persuade people, if your skill is high enough and therefore avoid some encounters)   Down: - Tasks, secondary quest are pretty boring (many fetch and kill-x-of those quests) - Crafting system somewhat unbalanced (mid-to-late game if you craft your own equipment you will be pretty overpowered and will kill most enemys with one hit)  - All in all a little bit to easy espacially some boss battles which therefore were pretty anticlimatic xD (minigames to pick locks is pretty easy even with few points in lockpicking *although the dispelling mini game can go eat it man, even with maximum level I still have problems but maybe it's because I suck at those things xD) - Graphics are average there are some good designed places, but other than that not really outstanding (and little variety in the faces, you will meet a lot of siblings but who knows maybe the genetic pool in Amalur is not really varied, that would explain the almost lack of facial animations espacially the main character which looks as emotional as a wet stone ;D ) - Some bugs and exploits (due to the developer going out of business :( ) - Best played with a controller  All in all it's a decent game, it's a real shame the developers went out of business before they could patch out all the bugs but you still get get enough entertainment if you go into it without expecting the next RPG-Hit.

Bought this on a whim despite many reviews stating it being too run of the mill, generic and feeling like a singleplayer mmoprg- namely Warcraft.  Never played Warcraft so i cant accurately confirm or deny that. Similar graphic style i guess but when i think mamapugu i think boring samey quests and doing the same ♥♥♥♥ over and over. Sure at the core it all boils down to 'get thing/kill thing' but that applies to Skyrim, the de facto gauge of this type of game aswell. How the writing packages it counts and in that regard Amalur does a good enough job, the reasoning to get/kill is always nicely integrated into the current setting - there are 'kill ten rats' quests but theyre by far not the majority. They had a writer on board and it shows altho he prolly didnt do stuff for every single miniquest  Regarding map design and such its all well done. The overworld is pretty big and varied, dungeons and interiors are made of prefab parts however its not that glaringly obvious.  It has an interesting weapon/armor crafting system in that you can break down stuff you find or buy into components with different attributes like health regen, resistances, more damage and such - the higher the skill the more components you can add which is really cool and fun but also broken but more of that later. Theres also alchemy which kinda works the same way.  Theres a class system in that you can invest in skills divided into three branches (worrior, stealthy dagger/arrow wuss and magix) and at a certain amount of points in a branch you can unlock specialization bonuses.  Melee combat is pretty fun. Each hit you take makes you reel regardless of actual damage. Sounds annoying and normally would be but that way you actually have to use dodging and blocking and be wary of positioning especially with multiple enemies - the whole thing avoids being a buttonmasher. Theres also combos and parries.   Its a very stable and bug free game, the downsides are all in the gameplay mechanics. First and foremost its way on the easy side mainly because it seemed to be balanced around a player type which doesnt like to do lotsa quests and craft his own stuff and mainly just rushes thru the main quest line - in a sandboxy rpg. If you explore youll be overleveled and if you craft your own stuff it will prolly be at least double as powerful as anything you find or buy.  Hard difficulty doesnt help with that, enemies take longer to kill but arent really a threath either with very few exeptions since if you play at least remotely smart youll have tons of potions or health regen from crafted equipment to negate the higher damage.  As mentioned the fun melee combat saves it somewhat since you cant be asleep at the wheel. Im not a fan of Oblivion style autobalance - if you use all the options in an rpg smartly you should get powerful, its just in this case its too easy to get there. I suppose you could gimp yourself by not using available options and try and keep the game balanced that way but what fun is that.  Another negative could possibly be that the melee combat is fun but not so the magic. There is a move list where you can see all the attacks and there seem to be like one direct damage spell, a heal, summon, shield and a teleport instead of dodge. They can be upgraded in functionality and i havent dipped into that branch at all so i might be wrong how it actually plays but it seems very barebone by comparision.  In conclusion its a very solid, well made and definitely fun game, however it doesnt exist in a game void and despite it not doing anything wrong really it has to measure itself against the towering giant that is Skyrim and thats a lost fight. So yeah if youre really sick of Skyrim but want to play something similar give this a spin - if not play Skyrim :d

I'm not much of one for writing reviews; I don't do it often, and have no practice at it. But, what I can say here, is that for years I've been looking for a game that's centered primarily, if not wholly, around Celtic mythology, rather than generic European medieval fantasy or feudal Asian mythology. This game delivered, moreso than I could have ever thought a game could. Why there haven't been more games featuring such strong Celtic themes is beyond me, but Kingdoms of Amalur: Recokoning showed that it can be done, and done very well. I was definitely impressed with the story of the game.  As far as gameplay, things were pretty good. Combat and controls felt better with a gamepad than mouse and keyboard, but that's never been a dealbreaker for me. I feel there could have been more done with combos and chaining attacks, because combat felt a little static after awhile, but it wasn't awful. Most quests(but not all; here's looking at you, Til's Collection) were interesting and often felt like an interesting task, rather than a chore to do for XP. The main quest line especially was fun, interesting, and kept me pulled in to the game. Factions you could join in the game I felt were pretty mediocre, and are your generic warriors, mages, and rogues factions. Their quests were fun, but I never really felt like my character truely belonged to the faction upon joining. The one major downside I felt in the game was gear drops. Almost always, what you can craft at each level was better than anything you could find, even rare named pieces or sets. As for the DLC, Teeth of Narros had a fun main story line, but for the most part it felt drawn out and monotonous. The side quests were pretty boring, and involved a lot of backtracking. Legend of Dead Kell was much better, and felt more involved.  One more note: This game is LONG. And I really mean long, especially if you are a completionist and want to do all of the side quests.

Enter Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning, which embodies the worst of this.   The principle concept of the main story is actually pretty interesting. Everyone is tied to fate except you. So you have the potential to change the course of history. Its a pretty good excuse for a chosen one scenario. There's still bugs, particularly when you try to remap your keys and a few crash to desktops, but that isn't the games greatest sin. Neither is the hideous menu system (which in turn makes crafting annoying at best). The worst part? In short, the game just becomes so boring. It became boring surprisingly early. It is a chore just to want to finish it. This is a direct result of the heavy investment in sidequests and how travel works. Running in a linear dungeon with the same tedious fights that are always resolved in the same manner because of a lack of needed for any real tactics and a surprising lack in variety of gameplay is also very boring.   That word best summarizes Kingdoms of Amalur: Boring.

Originally developed as an MMORPG, Kingdoms of Amalur is sort of like playing a great online game on your own little private server.   The advantage of this is that you don't have to play the game with any MMORPG weirdos. So if RPGs are your go-to for immersion, nobody's going to mess with your little fantasy here.  The disadvantage is that, weird as other players can be, it's actually very depressing playing a game like this on your own, and it can feel a lot like you're marooned in some sort of MMORPG-version solipsistic nightmare with all NPC eyes on you. This is the sad secret behind every single player game, but developers usually go to great lengths to hide it.   In this game you will feel alone because in playing it, you are alone. You will travel and discover (frequently beautiful) new lands, defeat big monsters, talk to boring NPCs, and collect silly looking gear. You will do it alone, and you will feel alone. The world is open and everything is permitted because there's nobody around to care about you or your choices. Your victories will feel as hollow as your losses because ultimately they are.  Stripped of narrative weight and consequence to accomodate the MMO format, stripped of human consequence because 38 Studios died and we needed a single player game instead, Kingdoms of Amalur is a great 'could have been' that bears the burden of both single player loneliness and MMO repetition. A theme park that everybody either left, or nobody ever made it to. Truly depressing.

At least everything you need for a high-fantasy RPG. NPC's are exchangeable all over the place, I cannot even remember a single name. Much less their background. The Graphics themselves are okay, not state of the art, but it's a game from 2012, so - oh, wait... 2012? ... Yeah, they could have done it better then. But it's still not 'bad', just 'okay'.  The map is gigantic and you are free to walk where you want. Unless you walk against a rock. Or against any other obstacle on your path. Even if it's just waist-high. And that upsets me every time in every game! But the music is lovely!   Fighting/Level System: The Action is nice, there are a lot of cool moves you can do, some really powerful spells and techniques. All combined, it makes quite fun to slay all that monsters. Also the game has a cool crafting-system, it's diversive and sometimes useful at the same time!  RPG really is my genre of choice, but it seems that I'm not a colorful, very-high-fantasy kind of player... I really gave it many chances to thrill me, but the atmosphere, the story, the character - all that failed to thrill me.

Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a great action RPG. The combat is smooth and entertaining and the attention to detail in the world is enough to keep you interested during the 35 or so hour gamelength. While there are hundreds of quests, and the game could probably be played for 70-80 hours, I recommend playing this as a story driven RPG. Focus on the main quest and the extremely entertaining faction quests, and the game never skips a beat. However, if you decide to tackle the 100 or so side quests, you will open a pandora's box of issues. For one, most of the side quests are generic. Thats not to say they are not well made, just that they are not anything beyond 'go here, kill this/find that, return'. On top of this, you can quickly over-level. There are ways to avoid over-leveling, but the easiest is to simply limit the number of side quests you do. If you take all of this into account, you'll find that Kingdoms of Amalur is a fun, well made RPG that has plenty of story and gameplay content.

You start out with room for 60 items i believe, and can buy bags so you can carry 110 or so by the end. The loot you don't use can be sold or salvaged for materials to craft new items.  The crafting is fun, you can combine professions to create really overpowered armor by the end if you find the correct materials. Overall: Get the game if you want a fun RPG with many hours of dungeon crawling, looting, leveling etc.

Given that this game came out in the same time frame as Skyrim, causing a cannibilization in sales, I think the base game and story is better than that of Skyrim. That being said, mods put Skyrim leagues above this game.   Aside from that, KO:A is an open world RPG where you can choose most of your own fate and change the fate of those around you based on your decisions. The world in this game is laden with fate and those who can read the strings of fate. You are an abnormality that bends fate to your own will and even use it as a weapon itself.   The game has 3 different combat styles that can greatly differ depending on how you play your character.  -The first is a warrior, the obvious and probably the main combat style for humans. You can go in with a heavy weapon, such as a greatsword for powerful slow swinging attacks. A warhammer to bash your enemies in with brutal force. Finally a longsword for closing the gaps and decent combos against your enemies.  -The second is the mage, and personally my favorite playstyle. The weapons here dont matter as much except to augment the damage of your skills. They consist of short range staffs, medium range chakrams, and long range staves. At higher levels you can summon a rain of fire, a lightning storm, or a condensed blizzard to take out your enemies.  -The last playstyle is that of an assassin. Their weapon set consists of daggers, faeblades, and bows. Short, medium, and long range respectively. The assassin deals mainly with bleeds and poison, causing damage over time and time to set up cunning traps to finish them off. Each of these paths get their own destinies (unrelated to the storyline) and buffs.   My main complaints with the game is the massive amount of gold fodder for either a house, upgrading your pack, or repairing weapons.  -I also have a problem how this game also tries to copy Diablo a little bit, though does it a bit poorly. As such you have sets in the game that rarely show up, and by the time you get anything more than one piece of the set, you've already out leveled it to the point where the set bonus won't bring it to par. Easily fixed by a shared inventory between characters, but not going to happen.  -Some of the skills and playstyles don't feel viable for progressing either. Though you can become an alchemist or blacksmith, you would spend an immense amount of time trying to progress by taking these paths.   All in all, I think this is a really good game, even after 4 years if it releasing, and I still come back to playing it time and time again, not even always on PC. I would suggest this game for anyone who enjoys open world RPGs.

I am reviewing this game as if I had paid the full asking price of 50 dollars. If I had done that I would have given it a rating of 6.5 out of 10. The game was definitely meant to be an MMO and the amount of side quests you will encounter while progressing through an otherwise fantastic story is staggering. If you take the time to learn about WHY you are fighting you will find an enjoyable narrative penned by fantasy legend RA Salvatore. Even on the hardest mode you will find the game is a good bit easy. As a straight mage I was able to use 2 or 3 spells and win every fight just casting them over and over while letting my undead minion heal me as he fought all the monsters on the map at the same time with a seemingly endless supply of hitpoints. And if you want to be even more overpowered simple enter reckoning mode and blow everything up all at once, and suck out their soul while you're at it, because... why not?   Now reviewed as a 10 dollar game, it's a DEFINITE buy. You can see where they had a lot of potential and if this were to be brought back by the right company it could be a game on par with Dragon Age or even Skyrim. But while we wait for that to happen, pick it up for a steal and enjoy the fast paced combat and fun story. And for 10 dollars, ignore the bugs and flaws and have a good time.

At 70% off for 12 usd, this game is a hell of a steal. The highlights are an open world environment very similar to the fable series, a choice system via dialogue very much akin to bioware games, random loot similar to arpgs, static monster spawns (clearing an area will cause monsters to respawn later). Another underrated aspect of the game is the destiny class system. A player is able to choose or combine from three professions (magic warrior or finesse) and receieve bonuses based on which they choose. At max level one will have 123 skill points, so to gain a purist bonus from one of those 3 classes, you need 109 points in a tree, a dual spec would be 55 in two or a universalist is 37 in each. Each specialization gives a different bonus such as archmage (109 magic) awarding fate orbs on kills, an ice damage teleport and elemental damage, whereas a combination of finesse/sorcery gives a poison damage blink among other things. With all that in mind, one is able to find a fateweaver in many parts of the game and respec for gold if they so choose. So one day you want to bash people with a hammer? No problem, tommorow you can play like a ninja.  The only problem I have with the game is the camera angles. For example, in one of the DLCs there is a race, which is easy enough, but to have to worry about camera angles adjusting while trying not to get slapped by a mob is somewhat annoying. All in all, you cant go wrong buying this huge game on sale at such a ridiculously low price.

This is probably the best RPG I have ever played. It is absolutely huge, both in scope and in actual size. This game was made in the Big Huge Engine, and I must admit that the world is pretty Big Huge. I'm about twenty hours into the game and I've barely progressed in the main campaign because there are so many fun and interesting sidequests. I always have at least ten active quests at a time.  The combat is really fun. It's simple, but it's also quite deep, and it even comes with fighting game-esque combos you can pull off for maximum damage to your enemies. Combat can be extremely varied and is significantly different for each class or multi-class, and even among each class there are different weapon types to spice things up even more. The only problem I have with the combat is that at times it can be a bit too easy, especially if you play like I do and you save all of your fate for boss battles, which makes many boss fights easier than taking on three or four smaller enemies.    This game has quite the pedigree. The world of Amalur was crafted by R.A. Salvatore, who is a best selling fantasy writer. I haven't read any of his works, but after playing this game I'm quite interested in looking into some of his stuff. The world is so fleshed out, and for a fantasy setting it's quite original. There are some fantastic ideas that really make this world stand out from settings such as Middle Earth or Tamriel, which are both great worlds, if a bit generic. The artwork was done by Todd McFarlane, and he brings such an amazing spin to everything, making everything in this game range from really pretty to horrifying and creepy. The lead designer of Oblivion also worked on this game, and in some areas that's very obvious, and all around it is very welcome. This game has some incredible genes going for it, with people from the top of their respective fields bringing something to this game.   This game is the best RPG I have ever played, and also possibly the best GAME I have ever played. I sunk over three hundred hours into Skyrim over a three year period. In the next year alone I forsee myself dumping significantly more than that into this game. It has fantastic replay value, and even if you don't replay it there's enough content in it to put in well over four hundred hours in a single game. With potentially over a thousand hours of content, I think that forty dollars for the game and DLC bundle is well worth the price, with some of the best value for money I have ever seen in a game. Love, love, love this game. Where to start.  Storytelling: This is THE reason to buy this game. Lore, quests, even random NPC chatter is amusing, interesting, and energetic. Combat: This aspect of the game I felt was it's shortcoming. Any weapon and path you choose always ends up the same. You can take on monsters 4 levels above you without effort pretty early into the game and storyline bosses are extremely easy. That being said, there was a nice feeling of impact with large weapons, but little to no impact with small weapons or magic. 4/10 (no confetti explosion).  Zones/Ambiance/Leveling: I group these things together because, to me, they all mean the same thing. If you like the zone, you will level faster, enjoy the quests and leveling process more and feel more 'in tune' and immersed in the game. The zones, frankly, ranged from unbelievable fantasy art with such attention to detail I couldn't believe it wasn't a cinematic... to utterly dry, boring dust bowl that I had to slog through and couldn't spend one more second in or I would quit. The variances of the zones ensure that anyone who picks up the game will have a good time, but I wish they hadn't sacrificed quality for variety. 6/10   DLC: I only bought 1 DLC, Legend of Dead Kel, and it was a good bit of fantasy candy to spend a couple days on, refurbishing a home, getting ridiculous gear and generally exploring a small private island you can put your personal touch on. Definitely a good pack for the cost. 8/10  Overall: 28/40 (70%) I really enjoyed this game over the course of a couple months. Casual player friendly and incredibly fun backdrop for an RPG adventure.

Amalur could've used a bit more polish before release. It has its ups but the downsides keep it from being awesome. If you're a fan of western action RPGs, chances are you'll get some enjoyment out of this, but for it to be considered great, takes a certain type of personal taste. Kingdom's of Amalur isn't a masterpiece, but it's not god-awful either, thankfully. Perhaps most of the issues could be fixed if a sequel is ever made, though that seems unlikely with the developer having gone bankrupt.  Mind you, I'm still going through the game so some of these points may change.  The good:  + Customizable combat. You can switch between a mage, rogue or warrior or a combination of any of them pretty easily, and there're multiple weapon types in the game, which feel varied enough to keep things interesting. Bonus points for making Chakrams NOT SUCK  + Executing entire packs of enemies through Fate is pretty fun to watch  + The atmosphere & exploration. I've rather enjoyed running around, discovering hidden loot caches and secret rooms, and the world's varied enough for me to enjoy exploring it  + The music. I found it rather relaxing in downtime, and exciting enough to fuel the fights in combat, though more variety would've been welcome  + The lore. I find this concept of a 'Fateless' person that is able to stand against the pre-determined destiny rather fascinating  The Bad:  - The graphics are a bit dated, even considering that the game went for a bit cartoony appearance which tends to age well  - Using Fate in combat is a quicktime event. I hate quicktime events. But at least it's brief  - Some weapons are broken, chief offenders being the bow and chakrams. You can completely stunlock some, if not all, enemies with them  - The inventory system is complete ♥♥♥♥. Each new thing takes up a spot and comparing items is a pain. And it takes ages to vendor everything, and you will be doing this a lot because most of the loot is completely useless.  - Money drops left and right. I haven't managed to drop below 60 thousand gold pieces yet, and it just keeps building up. And I'm not sure what there is to spend it on aside from inventory upgrades, since I've found all my best items  Personal pet peeves:  * There is no jump button, and jumping around in RPGs is something I rather enjoy * Default controls use Shift for Block, not Sprint, unlike pretty much every half-decent game made since the late 90ies.

This game is WEIRD. But I mean that in terms of everything it's trying to be. I feel like this is a game that, at the same time, wants to be Dragon Age, World of Warcraft and God of War. The good part is that it pulls this all off well enough. The story, while partaking of the age old trope that You and You alone, through a method remeniscent of Soul Reaver, are free from the bindings of destiny and actually have free will with which to change the world, is well written enough. The plot is decent for what it is, and you can see the hand of R.A. Salvatore all over it even before realizing that he hand a hand in writing the game. I really wish the PC could have been allowed to emit more of a personality, but the lack of such only gave me the chance to fill in the blanks with my imagination. The more action oriented gameplay is also neat and can be fun, though at times I felt the controls were so unresponsive that even with highly honed reflexes I still couldn't have dodged/blocked that hit that killed me in that last boss fight. It isn't so bad that you can't adjust, however.  The part where is resembles World of Warcraft is the part that buggers me, though. TL; DR: If you like fantasy RPG's this is a game you must play. solid 9/10.  Now i actually want to adress some things i like/dislike about the game,by the way i have about 100 hours in game, half of it was offline.  First of all, unlike in some reviews i saw, i will say professions are a big deal. My main has max blacksmithing and sagecrafting(gemcrafting) at max and my custom made armor and weapons are unmatched, i haven't found any weapon/armor pieces that is better than my gear yet. I like this, but there is a downside too, i have been running with same looking gear for more than half of the game. I mean, i craft new gear from time to time but in the end they look the same. Which is sad considering there are some great looking items in the game and i would like to wield them. And potion crafting is almost necessary in early game because you can just get locked from 2-3 enemies simultaneously attacking you and you die after 2-3 hits in early game on hard. But when you get some good gear it's almost useless.  Also, there are TONS of things to do, sidequests and errands(quests you can do over and over again) you can do, achievements to hunt, different playstyles you can try (for affordable money you can reset your skills/stats anytime in game), tons of lore to read (or listen from lorestones), huge world to explore. I love this, but yet again it brings something rather unpleasant too, you can pretty much get overpowered in midgame if you like to do any kind of quest/errand you find, which i tend to do. This makes the game really easy even on hard, specially if you craft your own gear.  Artstyle of the game, i think, is fantastic. Voicework is too good (specially Alyn Shir). Enemies are mostly unique. World design is superb.  I think the thing that could put a lot of people down is the level design, and game design in general. What i mean by that is, you can't jump, you can only jump from certain jump points. This actually is a big deal when you think about it. lets say you are on something that is about 30cm above ground. You just can't jump off or walk off and go on, minor things like that. Game design is, lets say, 'linear open world'. Map is consisted off very clear and distinct areas, which are again divided by sub areas, if you take a look at the map you will see what i mean.  Story is cliche but somewhat original too. I'd say it's a fresh take on the whole chosen one saves the world thing. I don't want to spoil much but it's just good.  Solid controls and a good combat system, almost all spells/weapons have at least 2 styles of attack, if not more. Like longsword has a basic swing if you just tap, a dash if you long press, if you double tap and pause and attack again it lifts the enemy up in the air etc. there are lots of combos and since you can equip two weapons at time to switch between, you can get a lot of cool interactions. There is also reckoning mode which has really cool finisher moves. There is also stealth in the game which i can not comment on because i never felt the need to use it since my character is a tanky beast.  There is also a twists of fate system which i find really cool, let's say you finished a long questline,main or side, that means you will probably get a twist of fade card, which will boost some effects on your character permanently. And sometimes actions you take during the questline will change the card you will get, and also will effect your game (for example in warsworn questline you can end up making them hate you or praise you, so they will either attack you on sight or be your allies.)  There is room for a lot of customization since there is no distinct classes in game, you can choose to spend your skill points in three skill trees without limitations, kind of like warrior,rogue and mage skill trees. You can make a rogue/mage, a warrior/rogue or so on. When you put enough point in a skill tree, or a combo of skill trees, you unlock destiny cards which will have effects varying from +% attack damage to changing your dodge roll with a shor ranged teleport.  There are 9 weapon types(sceptre,staff,chakram,longsword,greatsword,hammer,dagger,faeblade,longbow), lots of unique weapons with cool effects and looks (for example i had a pair of daggers which did fire damage at day and ice damage at night called 'shine and shadow'). Lots of armor types (leather, trollhide, sylvanite etc.) and lots of accessories with cool effects.  I want to talk about the DLC too, Weapons&Armor bundle is almost completely useless, i mean, it does give you a head start but it will only last about an hour or so. Then you will start to find better gear. I just made a character in which i rush the main quest, no sides, no exploring just straight marching on the main quest line. Even tho it means i neglect main means of getting gear, in about 2.5-3 hours i replaced all the gear i got from the DLC. So i will say pass on that. But Dead Kel and Naros are actually quite good. Both come with completely unique areas, enemies, lore, stories, characters and gear. Which i dig.  Now, i could just go on and on about this game but i will just say one more thing and finish my review, People love to compare this game to skyrim, while you are not as 'free' in this game i would say in terms of combat, artstyle, enemy/environment/gear variety, and lore this game is way superior. (About the lore thing, i know elder scrolls universe has tons of written lore and all but, in my personal experience, when i played skyrim i never actually considered, thought of lore, i didn't think the continent was built into the lore, it felt more like lore was built into the continent, which may not be the case but it just feeled that way.)  It's definetely a must play for Fantasy RPG fans.

A great action adventure role-playing game with a vast open world to explore and many quests to complete. Plenty of skill trees to try out and crafting to do, from potions to blacksmithing to enchantment. Suffers from clunky interface and at times it can feel grindy. All the characters are however, well voice acted and can bring a lot of life to the game. Finally, all cutscenes (and dialogue) are skippable. So yay to that. Worth purchasing during the sale, at $10 for base + all DLC.  Perhaps the greatest cons that are holding this game back in my opinion, is the very clunky interface when it comes to inventory and quest management. Instead of pressing, say, 'I' to open up an inventory screen, you have to press ESC to go to the menu and access your inventory from there. You can also only track one quest at a time, and can only view other quests on your local map provided that you're in the correct zone (this took a bit to figure out, but once it was figured out the single-quest tracking no longer posed a problem). Any other quests outside of your zone will not show up on your minimap. The game also has lots of loading screens, though they are rarely more than 10 seconds each, split between instances and interior / exterior transitions.   The game's combat can be very fun, a hack and slash sort of feel, with contextual 'moves' to use (i.e. pausing just before a second attack and you will launch enemies into the air) and the variety of skills to invest into can really mix up the gameplay. There's also a fate meter, which is essentially an execution bar where you go into a rage and deal extra damage whilst everything around you moves in slow motion, then you can execute enemies which kills all 'knocked down' enemies around you, whilst granting you bonus XP. You have your wizard, rogue and warrior skill tree. You have two weapon slots to quickly switch between as well as a 1-9 spell slot (casted by right clicking). The control might feel a bit console-like at first, but it's no where near as bad of a port as some other games have been (i.e. dark souls). Simply put, very playable. The graphics also look aesthetically pleasing, no real complaints.  There's a lack of 'open world' things to do beyond questing and hunting mobs, though there is more than enough dialogue to fill in each city / town / hub as well as letters and books to collect.  A revamped interface (as in, an actual in-game UI inventory screen, quest tracker and similar, would be significantly more palatable than its current clunky interface) and the addition of a few mounts could really improve this game.  Probably an 8/10. Definitely should pick this up during the sale (currently at 10$ for base game + all the DLC, which are worth the money).

The Story:   I found out about this game after doing some late night googling on Salvatore. 20 years ago I started reading his books and was amazed that I completely missed the fact that he worked on a game and it immediately went on my wishlist. The main story was okay, I don't really have any complaints but I didn't really feel any Salvatore coming through and I am unmoved. Anyone could have written/helped write the world and I wouldn't know any difference.   The Art:   Simultaneously I found out Todd Mccfarlane had some play in the art and I have an entire box of Spawn comics. My favorite childhood artist and writer together for one game, holy ♥♥♥♥. The color is great in the game but the lack of detail is mind boggling. Todd put so much detail into spawn comics and seeing character models without fingernails was just disgraceful. The graphics and animations are rather plain and nothing here is an artistic achievement. At one cutscene I recall a female soldier being shot in the back with an arrow and I think they tried to animate blood coming out of her mouth but it just looked like it was pouring out her face. Mediocrity is the theme for the art.   The Gameplay:   Through and through this is a single-player MMO action rpg. You could take any free to play mmo, remove the multiplayer and nothing about this game would outshine any of the uncountable amounts of games in the genre. Pretty much each zone has a town, each town has npcs with exclamation marks giving out fetch and kill quests. Each zone is linked together by a passage. There are basic tradeskills with the classic WoW style herb gathering, jewelcrafting , blacksmithing (except the last two you get regeants from chests and not nodes) and you don't need to invest in any of them although healing potions are the end all-most powerful item in the game as you can just spam them like Diablo 1. The skilltrees are decent, on par with something like diablo 2. The combat is mediocre to bad for an action game but better than an RPG like Skyrim. The main storyline is about 12 hours long and 'literally' 70% of the time you will be walking from one point to another like a really bad mmo, 20% of the time you will sit in inconsequential conversations and 10% fighting. The final boss was terribly boring/uninspiring/unchallenging and the entirety of the game was not challenging except at one point my main quest enemies became red (as opposed to neutral level enemies that are yellow, just like any mmo) and they were mostly unkillable. I went back to the surface leveled twice off yellow monsters (the 'open world' monsters scale to your level) came back and walked through the rest of the game without even trying.   Verdict:  Theres a lot of game here.. You could put 200 hours into fetch and kill quests if you wanted to and you can respec your skills as much as you want. If you (like me) have a history of playing mmos and you have no desire to grind out fetch quests ever again for the rest of your life just avoid this less than mediocre ftp-single player-mmo action game. If you have never played an mmo, or you love fetch and kill quests this game is ripe with them for many many hours.

It looks like most people have sung this game's praises, but I'll add my two cents to this game.  First and foremost, Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a fun game. You're a man/woman with no Fate, and as such can choose your Destiny out of 7 available styles. In addition, you have access to Reckoning Mode, where your attacks do more damage and you can finish your opponents by pressing 'A' or the corresponding key and mash a randomly selected button/key to gain extra experience.  The combat is in real time, and requires you to think on your feet. You've got 9 different weapon types, each with different moves and strategies required to rule the battlefield with. You can choose Primary and Secondary weapons to switch up your gameplay on the fly, which is really helpful. In addition, you can put 4 spells/skills into your slots and use at any time.  You also have access to a wide array of non-combat skills that help you create powerful weapons, craft helpful potions, and persuade the masses, to give a few examples. You'll want to stick with 3-4 main skills to level up, as you only have 40 levels to work with. Personally, Detect Hidden and Persuade are essential to see all the cool stuff available.  There are 5 main areas in Amalur, and each are unique in their appearance and ascetic. Each area has a lot of quests and places to explore. There are also 5-ish factions, each unique and fun to play through.  Due to your Fateless nature, you create Twists of Fate during big moments in the story and during faction quests. These Twists will benefit your stats, and will potentially change the faction you're working with for the rest of the game. These faction Twists have two paths you can take, meaning you have to play the game twice to see what both Twists offer.  Now this game, despite how good it is, does have some flaws. To begin with, there are some quests that have a chance to break, and will keep you from Fast Travelling if that happens, so save often. Persuasion has a percentage chance o work, but even at full Persuade, the highest chance to work is 95%, meaning you'll probably want to save if you are going to use that skill.  The targeting system is really bad, considering the nature of this game's combat. It's very difficult to change targets during combat, and sometimes you'll want to attack someone else during Reckoning Mode, but still keep wailing on an opponent who is already at the prompt. This game also has some quests that require you to escort/'ally' with NPC's that will fail your quest if they die. However, it is really easy for them to run off and get themselves killed while you're trying to fight off an opponent. It really doesn't help that enemies love to attack teammates, and I can't seem to find a way to draw aggro consistently.  In addition, the game's length, even if you skip the factions and most of the side quests, will still take a long while to finish. This can create fatigue, especially during the final haul, where it might feel like it'd be best to run past every enemy rather than deal with all the encounters you run into.  The DLC is also good, with Teeth of Naros being the best of the two expansions. The bosses in both are challenging but fun, and the areas added have plenty of content.  I bought this game and the DLC for $9.99 during a Sale, and I believe that the game is worth the initial $19.99, but I'd wait until the DLC's price goes down during another Sale to pick them up. This game can be frustrating at times, and I don't think I'll be playing again for a while, as this game can fatigue you with it's length. But Kingdoms of Amalur is a really fun game that you'll clock many hours into.

Some of the locations can also feel generic and some of the enemies attacks just feel like they're hacking away at your health, which can ruin any sense of strategy.   All of those are minor flaws, though. The biggest flaw of the game is when you're fighting multiple enemies at once. You'll be hacking away at an enemy, then another enemy will injure you and you'll automatically lock onto that new enemy. This can get frustrating when you're facing off with a boss and they summon a swarm of monsters. You're character will keep getting hit, hack at that enemy, get hit again, turn around and hack at that enemy, then get hit again and hack at that enemy. This can cause the fight to last forever because you're not locked on to one enemy long enough to actually kill them.  This may seem like a lot of complaints, but I've gotta admit that I still really like the game. The story is interesting, with a deep lore, and you can usually either work around or suffer through the enemy locking problem. The bottom line is that, despite its flaws, this game is very entertaining.

The title Kingdoms of amakur: Reckoning does not sound very promising. It sounds like the most generic pile of garbage, and in all honesty I expected it to be ♥♥♥♥. However, it turned out to be quite a bit better than I expected.  The highlight of the game is the combat. It's fluid, fast and fun. Nothing special about that really. It's a lot like a fighting system from a hack and slah game. The game does get REALLY combat heavy towards the end, which get's kinda annoying. The fighting can also get repeative, because it's not that complex, and there is just so much of it overall.Actually, my main problem with the game is that it's simply way too easy. I can count all of my deaths with 1 hand, and no, my hand does not have 36 fingers or anything like that. However, I do like the big world, and all the places that you can visit. I really wanted to explore the world and see new places, even though a lot of the tombs and caves are really bland.  On the other hand, the story and characters are really uninteresting. I never really cared about what was happening, and I barely remember any characters, Not exactly a good sign. I am also not a big fan of the visual style, just because it doesn't match the tone of the game at all.   This game is quite lengthy overall. I took me about +30 hours to finish, and in that time I almost got to the max level, and I beat quite a lot of the side missions, so that is pretty neat. I have heard that this game has enough content for over 100 hours, but I personally have my doubts about this. Many things in this game kinda give me the impression that this could have become a new fantasy RPG series, but that will most likely not be happening.  This game is not great, but it's not nearly as bad as I expected it to be. Even though the story and characters are weak, I still had a fun time playing through this game. Generally my feelings towards the game can be summarized with: It's fine
